title: 105_hr2023
content: The "Paycheck Fairness Act" is the short title of this Act. Congress finds that women have entered the workforce in record numbers but still earn significantly lower pay than men for equal work, leading to wage depression for working families and hindering the optimal use of labor resources. These pay disparities have spread through commerce and burdened the free flow of goods. Artificial barriers to wage discrimination based on sex persist, hindering the elimination of such discrimination despite the enactment of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 and the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Removing these barriers would positively impact the economy. The Equal Pay Act of 1963 aims to address unfair pay disparities in the economy, particularly for working women earning low wages. It promotes stable families by ensuring fair pay for all family members. Increased information and effective remedies are needed for women to enforce their rights to equal pay. Some employers have already taken steps to eliminate wage disparities in the workplace. The Equal Pay Act of 1963 addresses unfair pay disparities in the workplace, aiming to recognize achievements and promote fair pay for all. SEC. 3. ENHANCED ENFORCEMENT OF EQUAL PAY REQUIREMENTS. The Fair Labor Standards Act is amended to include a nonretaliation provision regarding wage discussions and enhanced penalties for violations. The Fair Labor Standards Act is amended to include a nonretaliation provision regarding wage discussions and enhanced penalties for violations. The amendment allows for class actions to enforce section 6(d) and recover liability, including expert fees. The Fair Labor Standards Act is amended to include enhanced penalties for violations, allowing for additional compensatory or punitive damages in cases of section 6(d) violations. The Fair Labor Standards Act is amended to include enhanced penalties for violations, allowing for additional compensatory or punitive damages in cases of section 6(d) violations. Additionally, parties can become plaintiffs in a class action to enforce section 6(d). SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF PAY INFORMATION BY THE EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION. Section 705 of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 is amended to require employers with 100 or more employees to maintain payroll records and submit reports to the Commission with pay information analyzed by race, sex, and national origin. Employee pay information must be kept confidential. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs will provide training on wage discrimination. The Secretary of Labor will conduct studies and provide information to address pay disparities between men and women by conducting research, publishing findings, sponsoring educational programs, and providing information to various organizations. The Secretary of Labor will address pay disparities by engaging with organizations, recognizing achievements, convening a national summit, and issuing voluntary pay guidelines for male- and female-dominated occupations. Establishment of the National Award for Pay Equity in the Workplace. The Robert Reich National Award for Pay Equity in the Workplace is established, with criteria for qualification including submitting an application demonstrating efforts to eliminate pay disparities between men and women. Additional requirements may be determined by the Secretary. The President or designated representative presents the annual award to businesses meeting qualifications determined by the Secretary. Recipients can publicize and use the award in advertising to help improve other US businesses. The term "business" in the context of improving pay disparities between men and women includes corporations, partnerships, professional associations, labor organizations, and similar entities. It also encompasses entities conducting education or training programs, as well as joint programs involving a combination of the mentioned entities. Increased resources for enforcement and education. Increased resources for enforcement and education include appropriations for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs. $36,000,000 is authorized for the EEOC to carry out various civil rights acts, while funds are also allocated for the OFCCP's necessary expenses. Contract Compliance Programs for necessary expenses of the Office authorized $10,000,000 in addition to sums otherwise appropriated. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission authorized $500,000 for training, and Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs authorized $500,000 for training as well. Authorized amounts for training under sections 6 and 7 are $1,000,000 for the Secretary of Labor. The funds will remain available until expended.
